bibl.title: Letter from Merritte W. Ireland to Albert E. Truby, August 20, 1931

div1.p: Ireland mentions Agramonte's death and requests that Truby and Kean write an accurate depiction of Agramonte's and Ames' work with the Yellow Fever Commission. He also describes a trip to France.

div1.head: Letter from Merritte W. Ireland to Albert E. Truby, August 20, 1931
div1.opener:
Gd Hôtel et Hôtel St-Aignan
ORLEANS
Téléph. 2013
R. C. Orléans 1668
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
Thursday
Aug. 20th 1931
My dear Truby,
div1.p:
The fact that I saw, by
accident, in a paper of the death
of Agramonte, gives me an excuse
to write to you. The paper said
that he was a member of the
Gorgas-Finlay board which discovered
how Yellow Fever was transmitted
& of course Kean will write an
obituary for his journal and it
seems to me that now is the
time to make an exact and
final statement of Agramonte's
position with the Reed Board-
Kean thought at one time, years
ago-- that he had done Agramonte
an injustice when he prepared
the statements of the work of the
Reed Board. In view of the comments you
made on Agramonte's speech at Detroit a year
ago - and your statement of what he really did
with the Board. I am inclined to think the
first opinion was not so far off after all
as you were so intimately associated with
Walter Reed for a long time and have such a
clear conception of all the details of that work
why dont you get together with Kean and
get a clear statement of what Agramonte did
in any article that may be published - and
incidentally in might come in handy to say what
R.P. Ames did- just to set the record straight
Now there - I have that off my chest

We drove to Tours from Paris last Monday
and have spent 3 interesting days seeing chateau's
of course I showed Mrs Ireland where we lived
in Tours and where our offices were It was most
interesting to me and Mrs Ireland enjoyed it
immensely. We saw six chateau's and will see
a couple more when we come through France
in Nov. to get our boat. We came here from
Tours today- seeing the chateau at Blois on the
way- Tell Kean that about 10 miles this side
of Blois. Mrs Ireland asked me whether
strange noise was she heard, and I told her
it was just the echo of the yell Kean gave
when Edmonson came very near running
us into a tree, one dark noisy Saturday
the later part of Sept 1918. Then he will tell
you part of the story. I will tell you the rest when
we have a visit some time

I cant tell you truly what a
wonderful time we have had
but everyday has been a real Celebration.
We go to Paris tomorrow, and then
to Rheims- Marcheau - Normandy.
Mrs Whiteland wrote Mrs Ireland that
rumor had it you were to Command
the Center. I do hope this is true, for
it means, to my notion just one
thing when Misume retires November
it be fine if Rup. should do what
I thought ought to happen & what
I know Reynolds would have done
if he had been made S.G.No- I
was not saying anything about the
recent promotion. I know it hurt your
feelings and those of many other
good fellows.

But enough. Give my love to
Jack and those fine pets- Mrs
Ireland gives me in best wishes
for you and Mrs Truby
